Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 09:20AM hopefor30 wrote: I am not stage 4, but I do have a fatty liver.    It was diagnosed when I had  an abdominal ultrasound for feeling bloated.    My liver enzymes are normal.    In my case, it was determined that tamoxifen has caused the fatty liver -- it is known for that, but I guess it is rare. I was sent to a liver specialist and it was decided that even though the tamoxifen is causing the fatty liver, I should stay on it.   I am premenopausal, so tamoxifen is the only treatment for me unless I have my ovaries removed. My onc said I need to be watched and if the liver enzymes go up at all, he would consider ovarian supression and switching me to an AI.    For now, I am still on tamoxifen.   I have also had some uterine lining issues and may end up having a hysterectomy  -- so I might just takek my ovaries out then.  The whole thing is just depressing.  I have had 7 surgeries over the last 3 years so I don't want another one, but I don't want a damaged liver on top of everything else.   So I havene't decided what I am going to do. I used to be hypothyroid as well -- but had my whole thyroid removed for thyroid cancer last June.  Not sure how that impacts my liver -- I take levoxyl and my TSH must be kept suppressed. Anyway, I hope you get an answer to your problems.    For what it's worth, none of my doctors were overly concerned about the fatty  liver.  I didn't like it, but I guess it's a little reassuring that they were not too worried.   I gave up alcohol after my breast cancer diagnosis  -- maybe had an occassional glass of wine at holidays -- now I don't drink at all.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 07:47AM hopefor30 wrote: I think that you need to move forward quickly and get whatever is in there out ---  and then you will know for sure.   Until it's out, they are still guessing.    I was diagnosed with DCIS via a biospy, had the MRI etc. and had an excisional biopsy (just like lumpectomy - don't know why they call it that).  Unfortunately in my case, a small 3mm tubular invasive was found after the excisional -- I also had a lot of DCIS - covered a 6cm span, although the largest part was only 1cm.    I ended up  having a mastectomy after my excisional biopsy due to 2nd opinion, my preferences and the fact that I was not satisfied with my cosmetic outcome after lumpectomy.   I am fairly small breasted and so much was removed, it looked terrible. I had DIEP recon at the time of mastectomy and I am happy with my results. Good luck with your decision -- but again, get it out and if you need to go back for more surgery, you will feel less pressured about making decision. M.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2010 06:59PM hopefor30 wrote: I am another one in the same boat.   Just had a complete hystercectomy with bilateral ovary removal.   It was my 8th surgery in the last 2.5 years.  I had been on tamoxifen for 2 years and had several cases of endometrial thickening.   Also felt bloated.   In the process of looking into that, "something" was seen on ovaries and like you, they couldn't say if it was malignant or not...probably not, but that's really not good enough is it? I was referred to a gyn surgeon who intially decided I should be followed by MRI.   After 3 months, I asked for a CA125 and it came back sllightly elevated.   That did it for me...ovaries had to come out.    I also opted to take out my  uterus because it was enlarged to the size of a 16-20 week pregnancy.   I think due to tamoxifen, but no one would admit that.    I had laparascopic total hysterectomy -- one night in hospital.   They did do a frozen section on ovaries in OR -- all was benign, so no big incision.   I have four tiny scars -- one in belly button, two on sides and one near pubic bone.   Very easy surgery compared to my DIEP reconstruction.  Easy recovery. I had no hot flashes for about two weeks.   I wonder if that means I had a lot of estrogen in my system and it took that long to go away or if I had so little it took a while for my body to notice the difference.    Hot flashes are regular but bearable -- a few a day and I feel hot at night, but no real night sweats. I have noticed joint pain in my neck and feet and hands. -- and I am still on tamoxifen which before gave me no side effects at all.   I see my onc in September and will transition to an AI -- I am very nervous about the side effects since I already feel achy from the loss of estrogen. For  me, I think I made the right decision.   I could not live with the elevated CA125 and just monitor things.    I have had both breast cancer and thyroid cancer in the last 3 years.   I do worry about all the stuff I read online about having a shortened life span from removing ovaries, but having cancer is worse.   I at least have some peace of mind now....I know I don't have ovarian cancer and I am glad to be rid of my oversize and uncomfortable uterus. Good luck with your decison.   Send me a PM if you have more specific questions.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 07:26PM hopefor30 wrote: I had a linear enhancement  on an MRI on my good side -- because I had tubular invasive and DCIS on the right, I made them biopsy it -- they were going to just watch it for 6 months.   I spent a lot of time researching linear enhancements and was convinced that I had DCIS on the other side as well.   In the end, it turned out to be an intraductal papilloma with ususal hyperplasia -- considered benign.    I had another MRI and mammogram after the initial MRI guided biopsy and this time both were clear.   The MRI had no enhancement at all, so it appears that it was all removed with the biopsy which made me feel better -- just in case it developed into something -- So, don't panic yet -- good luck and here's hoping for b9! Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 04:49AM hopefor30 wrote: The only way to determine if the clusters (which are most likely clusters of calcifications) are malignant is to have a biospy.    I couldn't wait to have the biopsy to find out -- unfortunately in my case, my clusters were cancerous -- Waiting is the toughest part of all this -- so I really don't think there are lots of questions to ask prior to the biopsy ---  most biopsies are benign -- I think they say about 80% -- so if it was me, I would schedule the biopsy as soon as possible.    Hopefully you can then relax and if not, at least you will know what you are doing with and can move forward with a treatment plan.   The one question I would ask is how soon you will get the results. The biopsy itself is not that big a deal -- it's the mental preparation.    They will numb you before they do it and you might have some mild swelling or bruising, but in my case, the biopsy was not painful. Good luck --

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 05:13AM hopefor30 wrote: Hi there, I am  also a tubular breast cancer....mine was only 3mm!  Very tiny, but I had a lot of DCIS -- what has always confused me is why the invasive cancer was tubular (grade 1, slow growing, etc) and my DCIS was grade 3 with necrosis.   The tubular was not found until after I had a lumpectomy for the DCIS.  Due to the amount of DCIS, I went on to  have a mastectomy with DIEP reconstruction.   I did consider bilateral as well, but could only have DIEP on one side, so decided to just have unilateral.   My breast surgeon did not recommend a bilateral -- so I went with that. So far, so good.   I had no chemo and no radiation.   I have been on tamoxifen for just over 2 years.  I guess I am less concerned about a recurrence than if I had a more aggressive cancer, but it still makes me nervous to have had cancer at all. I am also a thyroid cancer victim -- and yes, I said victim, because that is how I feel.   Barely two years after my breast cancer diagnosis I get thyroid cancer-- what's with that?   So while I am doing well, I am probably more paranoid than most. On the bright side, my onc does tell me frequently that tubular is low risk for recurrence and thyroid cancer is one of the "best" cancers to get....gee I feel so lucky.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 05:02AM hopefor30 wrote: I also had DIEP -- and had no pain at all.   The abdominal incisioin is not painful and while you are in the hospital they give you plenty of pain medication.  I would point out however, that it is not really comparable to a c-section -- the incision is mugh larger -- right across your whole abdomen...mine is very low since they my doctor cut in the same place as my previous c-section. I had twins and a laprascopic gallbladder surgery .....my stomach was a mess... lots of stretched out skin and my belly button was screwed up.   Havin the DIEP surgery was the one real bonus of all my surgery and getting cancer -- my stomach looks great -- it's flat - the saggy skin is gone...and my new belly button is nice and not all puckered like the gall bladder surgery left it. So, I would not worry too much about the pain, but it is a 4-6 week recovery...you won't be in pain, but you have to be careful -- no lifting etc....some doctors have you wear a stomach binder...I did not. I am two years post op and you can't even see my scar anymore....my PS says my abdomen scar is as good as they get --- Good luck.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 09:45PM hopefor30 wrote: I had a unilateral DIEP -- my surgery was about 8 hours long and I spent one week in the hospital (needed a blood transfusion, so that extended my stay). I have no regets at all, but the recovery is a long one, so don't get discouraged.  You will need help at home for at least the first week -- more if you have kids - I had help for 3 weeks.   You will be tired and need to rest and not push yourself too hard. I slept in a recliner for about 4 weeks as it was uncomfortable to lie down in bed.   I have heard of many other women who even rented hospital beds or recliners.  You will also need loose fitting clothing and tops that open down the front -- you won't be a fashion statement for awhile, especially while you have drains in --  You should post this question on the reconstruction board -- there are lots of women there who have had DIEP and can fill you in. Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 07:42AM hopefor30 wrote: I just thought I would add another perspective.   I was absolutely terrified to have DIEP surgery, but I did it.   Granted, I did it at the same time as my mastectomy so I only had one surgery, but that's exactly why I did it all at once.   I knew that I would not have the courage to go back for more surgery after the fact, so I can imagine how you feel. DIEP is a long, tough surgery.   There is no question about that.   The recovery is long and I actually had several complications as well.   But I am glad that I did it.    Although my new boob isn't perfect, I am able to get up every day, get dressed, wear a normal bra and no one would ever know I had had a mastectomy. I think this is something that has helped me feel better about myself.   I worry enough as it is about recurrence and how long I will be around for my kids (14, 11, 11) and no having to feel flat into the bargain is one less thing to depress me. I don't know that I have really helped.   Whether you have the surgery or not is a tough decision.    I will say that I was less afraid to have my second stage surgery and I am considering a third in the fall to get a nipple to finish up. Have you ever met with a plastic surgeon?   It might be worth a consult to see if the meeting makes you feel more or less frightened of surgery -- at least discuss the options. Good luck. M.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 11:03AM hopefor30 wrote: I also had a drain for 4 weeks -- and it also partially self-ejected 3 times -- the first time I had to go into the ER and have it restitched (it was on a Sunday) -- the second time I noticed it was further out (the black dot on the tube was moving downwards) the PS reattached it in his office and the last time it was practically out when my visiting nurse was visiting -- ended up back in the PS office and it was finally pulled -- was not quite under 30cc at the time.   Unfortunately for me, I ended up with an infection about a week after the drain came out -- boob swelled and turned red -- not fun -- If the tubing slides out, but is still attached, the suction can be compromised -- that happened to me twice.   Also, I was told to make sure I did strip the drain continually -- and Kathy is right, make sure the bulb is flattened or you will lose suction.   A couple of times the bulb popped during the night and the drainage would stop until I stripped the drain and flattened the bulb. Good luck -- they are awful things, but necessary. M.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 07:38AM hopefor30 wrote: I also started off with "just DCIS" but after an excisional biopsy a small 3mm tubular breast cancer was found.  I went on to have a mastectomy and the sentinel node biopsy.   The masectomy was required because the DCIS was widespread.   The SNB is standard with invasive cancer.   I had 6 nodes removed and had both the radioactive tracer and the blue dye.   The tracer injection did not hurt.   The dye was injected in the OR so I didn't feel it. I had one of the most ambiguous resutls which was very unsettling.   Two pathologists saw isolated tumor cells (still considered node negative) in one node.   A third favored benign displaced epithelium (from previous biopsies) -- I had the Oncotype DX test and no chemo and no futher lymph node removal.   I trust my doctors, but the ambiguity of the SNB still bothers me if I think about it. If it makes you feel any better, I had very little discomfort from the SNB and have no numbness in my armpit at all.    My breast, however, is numb.   I had DIEP recon and it looks pretty good. M.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 09:14AM hopefor30 wrote: I was also pushed to the lumpectomy decision by my first group of doctors, but I knew I did not want one.   I had 6cm span of DCIS and upon "excisional biopsy" they found a 3mm tubular cancer.  I was also afraid of radiation. The long term survival is the same with both treatments, but the rate of recurrence of DCIS with a lumpectomy/radiation is higher.  I think when I researched it, there is a 20-30% chance it will recur and 50% of those recurrences are invasive.   I also have small breasts -- the excisional biopsy, which was really a lumpectomy, removed almost half my breast tissue and left me very deformed. To make a long story short, I sought a second opinion with another group of doctors who agreed that I should have the mastectomy due to the amount of DCIS.   I do not regret my decision and sometimes wonder whether I should have had a bilateral, but will hope for the best on the other side. I also had immediate reconstruction -- and I believe I would have had a better cosmetic result without the initial "excisional biopsy/lumpectomy" that I was told I had to have right away. M.
Posts.Title: Feeling pressured to have lumpectomy instead of mastectomy otter irishdreama

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 07:44AM hopefor30 wrote: Hi Heidi -- I am in Boston too and was treated at Beth Israel -- where did you go for your first opinion? My situation was opposite to yours -- my first opinion said lumpectomy only and BI said mastectomy -- I had a 6cm span of DCIS and a 3mm tubular invasive cancer.    Due to the amount of DCIS I knew I wanted a mastectomy. I have been very happy with BI -- doctors there are great and I have full confidence in their ability, but I can see why you are upset.  I can't imagine they would recommend saving the breast if they thought it was risky --  who is your surgeon?  Another thing to consider is whether or not you will get a good cosmetic result with the lumpectomy.   My lumpectomy (which was done at Newton Wellesley) took out almost half my breast -- it looked caved in and deformed and my breast surgeon at BI said it would get worse after radiation. Since I didn't want radiation and it didn't look good anyway, I had no trouble going with the mastectomy -- I had unilateral DIEP recon and am happy with the results which look much better than my deformed boob after lumpectomy. I know this is a tough decision, but remember -- it is your decision.   Since BI thinks you are OK to save the breast, you have that option -- if you are not comfortable with that, then you can have a mastectomy.   It is worse when they recommend a mastectomy and you don't want one..... Good luck with your decision and if you have any questions about doctors at BI, feel free to PM me. M.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 03:26PM hopefor30 wrote: Your tumor needs to be ER+ and until recently you had to be node negative.   I am not sure, but they might be doing the test now for node positive.    And yes, it basically estimates your chances of a recurrence and gives you a score which is rated low, medium or high risk.  It is also used to determine if chemo is beneficial -- low risk is usually no chemo, medium risk can go either way and high risk gets chemo, although it is not the only deciding factor that doctors use.   It is not 5 years, but estimates chance of recurrence over a 10 year period and assumes that you WILL be treated with tamoxifen.  Lots of women are using it to help with the chemo decision, but make sure you confirm insurance coverage upfront unless you are willing to pay the $3650 price tag anyway.     Mine was not covered -- I did however get a low score and was able to opt out of chemo -- M.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2009 08:18AM hopefor30 wrote: Well, I am another one with two cancers -- I was diagnosed with bc in 2007 and a separate thyroid cancer (papillary) in 2009.   The second diagnosis is tough -- just when you try to forget about cancer (and we all know you can't completely forget)  I got hit with another one. I "discovered" my own thyroid nodule.   Had strange sensation in my throat - lots of reflux, and some trouble swallowing -- my neck felt funny.   Told my PCP, who was also an endocrinologist, that something was wrong with my neck and since I had had bc I was worried about lymph nodes in my neck.    She repeately told me I was fine and not to worry -- needless to say she is no longer my doctor. When I didn't get anywhere with her, I talked to my onc who ordered an ultrasound - nodules were found, biopsied and were cancerous.   I have since had my thryroid removed and had radioative iodine treatment.   And my thryoid cancer was stage 3 -- microscopically outside the thyroid -- and I am convinced it might not have been if I hadn't been stalled by almost 6 months by my incompetent doctor. So, my advice is to get thyroid nodules checked out -- I knew something wasn't right with me and I was right.   For now, I am thyroid cancer free, but thyroid cancer, although curable and "mild" can still recur at any time.  So, even though the prognosis is very good, you still have the stress of being monitored and undergoing body scans etc. every 6-12 months. Is thyroid cancer connected to breast cancer?   Who knows?  I have asked my onc and have been referred to the cancer genetics divison at my hospital -- they do not think it is related, but have agreed they will meet and talk with me since it is rare.....but after reading this thread, it appears I am not alone.  I am convinced it is connected....just hope I don't have some bad gene that can be passed onto my kids.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 06:49AM hopefor30 wrote: This is an interesting thread.   I did have DIEP reconstruction but agonized over the decision during the 3 months that I had to wait to get my surgery.    I was terrified, but knew if I did not have immeidate recon, I would never go back for more surgery.   It is a very tough surgery, no doubt about it and I had complications as well.  And once you have it done, you are committed to seeing it through.   It took me almost 6 months to feel totally normal.  I am happy that I had it done and I am happy with my results, but if I knew ahead of time all that I would go through, it might have made my decision to reconstruct even tougher. It is a very personal decision and for those who choose not to reconstruct, you can always change your mind at a later date. I did notice one thing said in this thread that bothered me, however.   Someone stated that when you are having reconstruction, they "save" some breast tissue to do so during the mastectomy.   That is just not true!   Do you seriously think they would compromise your health for cosmetic reasons?   I don't believe that is true in my case or in any case where recon is performed.   If you choose not to reconstuct, that's fine, but please don't imply that those of us who have have compromised our health for cosmetic reasons.   M.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 09:10AM hopefor30 wrote: I had extensive DCIS -- all in one quadrant, but a lot of it.   I had a mastectomy for that reason.   Initially I had a lumpectomy -- they called it an excisional biopsy --  and I then went on to have the mastectomy with immediate DIEP recon.  Just thought you might like to know that I look better with the recon.   My breast was very deformed after the lumpectomy and did not look good at all -- I am relatively small breasted -- so after the extensive area of DCIS was removed, there was a big dent in my boob.   It also hardened near the dent and was uncomfortable. With the recon -- I have a soft, comfortable and not bad looking boob -- so lumpectomy is not always the best for appearance.    And there is the added bonus of not worrying about more DCIS somewhere else.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 08:23AM hopefor30 wrote: Yes, it is normal not to be staged at this point.   To determine the actual size of the tumor, you have to have surgery.  How do you know about the lymph nodes?   Did they biopsy one of them?   Usually lymph nodes are biopsied via sentinel node biopsy during surgery. Regarding lumpectomy vs. mastectomy -- it is really a personal decision.   If your tumor is large or there is more than one, they often recommend mastectomy.   My tumor was tiny, but I had a lot of DCIS, so I opted for a mastectomy and had immediate DIEP reconstruction which was the right decision for me.     Although they tell you that survival for mastectomy and lumpectomy are the same, I believe local recurrence (in the same breast) is higher with lumpectomy -- also I wanted to avoid radiation which I was able to to by having a mastectomy. Good luck - you are at the worst part of this journey -- being diagnosed -- I know it doesn't seem possible, but you will feel better after you meet with your doctor and have a plan. M.

In my case, I lot of tissue was also removed -- I had a 6cm span of DCIS -- I ended up having a mastectomy with DIEP recon -- the crack is gone and it now looks pretty good.  If yours doesn't improve, you could always consult with a plastic surgeon.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 08:43AM hopefor30 wrote: I had one abdominal drain for 1 week, the other for 2 1/2 weeks and the most uncomfortable of all, the breast drain in my armpit for 4 weeks!  Ugh!   My surgeon likes to have them under 25cc a day for two days running before they are removed.    My breast drain actually started to slide out twice while it was still draining a considerable amount -- had to go to the emergency room once and the doctor's office once to have it re-sutured --  my armpit was so sore.   The drain was finally removed when I was down to 35cc because it had started to come out again.....leaked fluid for a couple of days and then it stopped.    I did OK for a week, but now I am worried that my reconstructed breast is expanding and fluid is building up -- I am off to the PS once again on Thursday to get it checked.   I hope I do not have to have a new drain put in because the old one was causing me pain 24/7.   Just as the pain started to go away, I get swelling! As to showering, my PS recommended a product called the kangaroo belt -- made by Turner Products -- it is a terrycloth belt with a pouch that goes around your waist when you shower and holds the drains -- very easy to use --  I bought two and took turns drying them out between showers.   The hospital where I had my surgery had also attached clips to the drains so when changing they could be clipped to your clothes, robe, etc so they wouldn't get caught. Say a prayer I don't need my drain back! M.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 05:39AM hopefor30 wrote: I had a vacumn assist MRI guided biopsy and it was a piece of cake -- just shows that not all experiences are the same.   I think a lot of it depends on the skill of the radiologist doing the biopsy.   I previously had a stereotactic biopsy which was more painful after the fact than the MRI and I had much less bruising with the MRI guided biopsy. It is not the MRI that makes the biopsy more or less painful.   The MRI is just the method to locate what they are trying to biopsy. -- Sometimes it is the location of the tumor that causes more or less pain -- depending on how difficult it is to access it. Don't panic too much based on what your client told you -- more painful than a double mastectomy?   No way, in my case.   Just tough to lie on that uncomfortable MRI table for awhile without moving....you'll be fine. M.
